photo.caption: A view of the 1900 block of Bonitz Street, where Gregory Jackson and Sophia Pope's youngest son was poisoned by lead paint in a home they rented. More than 90 percent of the houses in Philadelphia were built before the 1978 lead-paint ban.
photo.title: LEAD30-A

photo.caption: This photo was taken by Gregory Jackson in December 2015 when workers hired by the landlord burned lead paint with a blowtorch and splashed the walls with turpentine prior to sanding and scraping the lead paint.
photo.title: LEADXX-HHH

photo.caption: Camilla Hardee Mickens and her great-aunt moved into the Bonitz Street house after Sophia Pope and Gregory Jackson moved out. She stands in front of a wall that had been burned but has since been repainted.
photo.title: LEADXX-S

photo.caption: The photo on the left was taken in the Bonitz Street property by Gregory Pope in December 2015 when workers hired by the landlord burned lead paint with a blowtorch and splashed the walls with turpentine prior to sanding and scraping the lead paint. The photo on the right was taken by Inquirer photographer Jessica Griffin in September 2016 and shows the entryway with fresh paint.
photo.title: LEAD30-I_before_after_bkg_1200

photo.caption: Steven Vena, a lead-risk assessor with Criterion Laboratories, takes dust-wipe samples throughout the Bonitz Street house, including the basement area where Vaughn Jackson and his brothers used to play.
photo.title: LEADXX-K

photo.caption: Lead inspector Steven Vena takes a dust-wipe sample in the bedroom of the Bonitz Street house in September.
photo.title: LEADXX-P
